curam.util.common.path
Interface Path

public interface Path

A path represents a series of steps that identify some data. In string form, paths are expected to represent steps that are separated by "/" characters. The steps can be arbitrary identifiers. Whitespace will be trimmed when the steps are parsed. If there are no step separator characters, the whole string becomes a single path step. An empty string, a string containing only whitespace, or a single separator character is interpreted as a path with no steps. Sequential separators, or those delimiting whitespace are treated as delimiting no step.

Method Detail

pathFrom

Path pathFrom(int stepIndex)
Gets a new path that includes the step at the specified index and all following steps to the end of the path. If the index is beyond the last step in the path, an empty path is returned, i.e., "/". If the index is negative, an exception will occur.

Parameters:
stepIndex - The index of the first step to include in the new path.
Returns:
The path from the indicated step to the end.
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is negative.

pathTo

Path pathTo(int stepIndex)
Gets a new path that includes only the steps up to, but not including, the step at the specified index. If the index is zero or negative, an empty path is returned, i.e., "/". The index must not be greater than the number of steps.

Parameters:
stepIndex - The index of the first step that will not be included in the new path.
Returns:
The path up to the indicated step.
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is greater than the number of steps in the path.

extendPath

Path extendPath(java.lang.String... extendedPathStrings)
Creates a new path that extends this path with further steps given in the path strings. There can be one or more path string and each can contain one or more steps. All of the paths are concatenated. Any null path strings will be ignored.

Parameters:
extendedPathStrings - The strings defining the paths to use to extend this path and create a new path.
Returns:
A new path that represents an extension of this path.

extendPath

Path extendPath(Path... extendedPaths)
Creates a new path that extends this path with further steps from other paths. There can be one or more paths and each can contain zero or more steps. All of the paths are concatenated. Any null paths will be ignored.

Parameters:
extendedPaths - The paths to use to extend this path to create a new path.
Returns:
A new path that represents an extension of this path.

applyIndex

Path applyIndex(int stepIndex,
                int indexValue,
                boolean search)

Creates a new path that replaces the first empty predicate on the indicated step with a predicate that has the given index value. If there is no such step, this path is returned. If the step has no empty predicate and the value of the search argument dictates what happens next. If the value is false, then nothing is changed and this path is returned. If the value is true, then the next step is chosen and the index is applied there instead, and so on. If there are no more steps left and no change was made, this path is returned.

For example, if the first step is selected, the index value is one, and searching is disabled, then "/a[]" becomes "/a[1]", "/a/b[]" remains unchanged (the predicate is not on the first step), and "/a" remains unchanged (there is no predicate). If searching were enabled, then "/a/b[]" would have become "/a/b[1]", as the second step would be selected after failing to change the first step.

Parameters:
stepIndex - The index of the step to be indexed.
indexValue - The value of the index to apply to the step.
search - true to indicate that the change should be applied to the steps after the indicated step if that step has no empty predicate.
Returns:
A new path with the index applied, or an unchanged path if there was no empty predicate.

applyIndex

Path applyIndex(int stepIndex,
                java.lang.Object indexValue,
                boolean search)
Creates a new path that replaces the first empty predicate on the indicated step with a predicate that has the given index value. This is the same as Path.applyIndex(int, int, boolean), but the predicate will be the given object, not an integer. The object must not be modified after it has been applied as a predicate value. If the index value object is null, then a new path is not created and this path is returned unchanged.

Parameters:
stepIndex - The index of the step to be indexed.
indexValue - The value of the index to apply to the step.
search - true to indicate that the change should be applied to the steps after the indicated step if that step has no empty predicate.
Returns:
A new path with the index applied, or an unchanged path if there was no empty predicate.

getStep

Step getStep(int stepIndex)
Gets the step at the given index. The first step has index zero.

Parameters:
stepIndex - The index of the step to get.
Returns:
The required step.
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index does not correspond to a step in the path.

size

int size()
Gets the number of steps in the path.

Returns:
The number of steps.

isEmpty

boolean isEmpty()
Indicates if the path is empty, i.e., it has no steps. Testing if the size is zero has the same effect.

Returns:
true if the path has no steps, false otherwise.

equals

boolean equals(java.lang.Object object)
Determines if this path is equal to another path. Paths are equal if they are not null, are both paths (and not some other type), they have the same number of steps, and each step is equal.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
object - The path (or other object) to be tested for equality with this path.
Returns:
true if this path is equal to the given path, false otherwise.

startsWith

boolean startsWith(Path path)
Determines if this path starts with the same steps as the given path. The steps are tested for equality. If this path is shorter than the given path, the steps are not tested at all and false is returned.

Parameters:
path - The path to test for equality with the initial steps of this path.
Returns:
true if this path starts with the same steps as the given path, false otherwise.

toString

java.lang.String toString()
Converts the parsed path steps to a string. This will not include any whitespace that was trimmed from the original path. An empty path is represented as a single "/" character. A leading "/" character will be added if one was not present originally.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
The string representation of this path.
